{{Infobox software | logo = [[File:TestDisk-logo.svg]] | screenshot = [[File:Testdisk.png|250px]] | developer = Christophe Grenier | latest_release_version = 6.12 | latest_release_date = {{release_date|2011|05|11}} | platform = [[Cross-platform]] | interface = [[Command line interface|CLI]] | status = Active | genre = [[Data recovery]] | programming language = [[C (programming language)|C]] | license = [[GNU General Public License|GPL]] ([[free software]]) | website = [http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk] }} '''TestDisk''' is a [[free software|free]] data recovery utility. It was primarily designed to help recover lost data storage [[partition (computing)|partitions]] and/or make non-booting disks bootable again when these symptoms are caused by faulty software, certain types of viruses or human error (such as accidentally erasing a partition table). TestDisk can be used to collect detailed information about a corrupted drive which can then be sent to a tech for further analysis.
== Supported operating systems == TestDisk supports these [[operating system]]s: * [[DOS]]: real or in a Windows 9x DOS box * [[Microsoft Windows]]: [[Windows NT|NT4]], [[Windows 2000|2000]], [[Windows XP|XP]], [[Windows Server 2003|2003]], [[Windows Vista|Vista]], [[Windows 7]] * [[GNU/Linux]] * [[FreeBSD]], [[NetBSD]], [[OpenBSD]] * [[SunOS]] * [[Mac OS X]]
== Supported partition table type == TestDisk recognizes the following [[disk partitioning]]: * [[Apple partition map]] * [[GUID Partition Table]] * PC/Intel Partition Table ([[master boot record]]) * Sun [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]] [[slice (disk)|slice]] * [[Xbox]] fixed partitioning scheme It also handles non-partitioned media.
== Partition recovery == TestDisk queries the [[BIOS]] or the [[operating system]] in order to find the [[data storage device]]s ([[hard disk]]s, [[memory card]]s, â¦) and their characteristics ([[Logical block addressing|LBA]] size and [[Cylinder-head-sector|CHS]] geometry). TestDisk can<ref>Debra Littlejohn Shinder, Michael Cross (2002). ''Scene of the cybercrime'', page 328. Syngress. ISBN 978-1931836654.</ref> * Recover deleted partition * Rebuild partition table * Rewrite the [[Master boot record]] (MBR)
TestDisk does a quick check of the disk's structure and compares it with the partition table for entry errors. Next, it searches for lost partitions<ref name="debian_admin">Ido Perelmutter - Debian Administration, [http://www.debian-administration.org/articles/420 Recovering from file system corruption using TestDisk] </ref><ref name="softpedia">Ionut Ilascu, [[Softpedia]], [http://www.softpedia.com/reviews/windows/TestDisk-Review-32579.shtml Your HDD Is Missing a Slice? Try TestDisk for a change]</ref> of these [[file system]]s: * [[Be File System]] ([[BeOS]]) * [[BSD disklabel]] (FreeBSD/OpenBSD/NetBSD) * [[Cramfs]], Compressed File System * DOS/Windows [[File Allocation Table|FAT]] 12, 16, and 32 * Windows [[exFAT]] * [[Hierarchical File System|HFS]], [[HFS Plus|HFS+]] and HFSX, [[Hierarchical File System]] * [[IBM Journaled File System 2 (JFS2)|JFS]], IBM's Journaled File System * Linux [[ext2]], [[ext3]] and [[ext4]] * Linux RAID ** RAID 1: mirroring ** RAID 4: striped array with parity device ** RAID 5: striped array with distributed parity information ** RAID 6: striped array with distributed dual redundancy information * Linux Swap (versions 1 and 2) * LVM and LVM2, Linux [[Logical Volume Manager (Linux)|Logical Volume Manager]] * [[Novell Storage Services]] (NSS) * [[New Technology File System|NTFS]] (Windows NT/2000/XP/2003/Vista/2008/7) * [[ReiserFS]] 3.5, 3.6 and 4 * Sun Solaris i386 disklabel * [[Unix File System]] UFS and UFS2 (Sun/BSD/â¦) * [[XFS]], SGIâs Journaled File System
However, it's up to the user to look over the list of possible partitions found by TestDisk and to select the one(s) which were being used just before the drive failed to boot or the partition(s) were lost. In some cases, especially after initiating a detailed search for lost partitions, TestDisk may show partition data which is simply from the remnants of a partition that had been deleted and overwritten long ago.
A step by step guide<ref name="stepbystep">[http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk_Step_By_Step TestDisk Step by Step]</ref> explains how to use this software. TestDisk can be used in [[Computer forensics]] procedure<ref name="sleuthlit">Presentation of TestDisk in [http://www.sleuthkit.org/informer/sleuthkit-informer-15.txt The Sleuth Kit Informer]</ref>, it supports the EWF file format used by [[EnCase]].
== Filesystem repair == TestDisk can deal with some specific logical filesystem corruption<ref>Jack Wiles, Kevin Cardwell, Anthony Reyes (2007). ''The best damn cybercrime and digital forensics book period'', page 373. Syngress. ISBN 978-1597492287.</ref>: * [[File Allocation Table]], FAT<ref name="fatfix">[http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/Advanced_FAT_Repair Advanced FAT Repair]</ref> ** FAT12 and FAT16 *** Find filesystem parameters to rewrite a valid boot sector *** Use the two copies of the FAT to rewrite a coherent version ** FAT32 *** Find filesystem parameters to rewrite a valid boot sector *** Restore the boot sector using its backup *** Use the two copies of the FAT to rewrite a coherent version * [[exFAT]] ** Restore the boot sector using its backup * [[New Technology File System|NTFS]]<ref name="ntfsfix">[http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/Advanced_NTFS_Boot_and_MFT_Repair NTFS boot sector and MFT repair]</ref> ** Find filesystem parameters to rewrite a valid boot sector ** Restore the boot sector using its backup ** Restore the Master File Table (MFT) from its backup * [[Extended file system]]s, [[ext2]], [[ext3]] and [[ext4]] ** Find backup superblock location to assist [[fsck]]<ref name="ext2fix">[http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/Advanced_Find_ext2_ext3_Backup_SuperBlock Locate ext2/ext3/ext4 backup superblock]</ref> * [[HFS+]] ** Restore the boot sector using its backup
== File recovery == When a file is deleted, the list of disk clusters occupied by the file is erased, marking those sectors available for use by other files created or modified thereafter. If the file wasn't fragmented and the clusters haven't been reused, TestDisk can recover the deleted file: * FAT file undelete<ref name="fat_undelete">[http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk:_undelete_file_for_FAT FAT file undelete]</ref> * NTFS file undelete<ref name="ntfs_undelete">[http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk:_undelete_file_for_NTFS NTFS file undelete]</ref> * exFAT file undelete * ext2 file undelete<ref name="ext2_undelete">[http://www.cgsecurity.org/wiki/TestDisk:_undelete_file_for_ext2 ext2 file undelete]</ref>
== Popularity == TestDisk and [[PhotoRec]] (by the same author) have been downloaded more than 150,000 times in July 2008 from the primary website. In fact these utilities are even more popular as they can be found on various [[Linux]] [[Live CD]]s: * [[Recovery Is Possible]] * [[Knoppix STD]] * [[GParted]] Live CD * [[Iloog]] * [[Parted Magic]] * PLD Live CD and PLD RescueCD, based on [[PLD Linux Distribution]] * Slax-LFI, a [[Slax]]-derived distribution * [[SystemRescueCD]] * [[Trinity Rescue Kit]] * Ubuntu Rescue Remix, an [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] derivation They are also packaged for numerous [[Linux distribution]] * [[ALT Linux]]<ref name="ALT_Linux">[http://alt.linux.kiev.ua/srpm/testdisk/get TestDisk on ALT Linux]</ref> * [[ArchLinux]] Extra Repository<ref name="ArchLinux">[http://www.archlinux.org/packages/?q=testdisk ArchLinux Extra Repository]</ref> * [[Debian]] contrib<ref name="Debian_contrib">[http://ftp.debian.org/debian/pool/main/t/testdisk/ TestDisk on Debian]</ref> * [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]] Extras<ref name="Fedora_Extras">[http://download.fedora.redhat.com/pub/fedora/linux/releases/ TestDisk in Fedora]</ref> * [[Red Hat]] Epel<ref name="RedHat_Epel">[http://download.fedora.redhat.com/pub/epel/ TestDisk in Red Hat Epel]</ref> * [[FreeBSD]] ports<ref name="FreeBSD_ports">[http://www.freshports.org/sysutils/testdisk/ TestDisk in FreeBSD ports]</ref> * [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]]<ref name="Gentoo">[http://packages.gentoo.org/package/app-admin/testdisk TestDisk in Gentoo]</ref> and Gentoo Portage<ref name="Gentoo_Portage">[http://www.gentoo-portage.com/app-admin/testdisk TestDisk in Gentoo Portage]</ref> * [[Mandriva]] contrib * [[PLD Linux Distribution]] * [[Source Mage]] GNU/Linux<ref name="Source_Mage">[http://distro.ibiblio.org/pub/linux/distributions/sourcemage/codex/test/disk/testdisk/ TestDisk in Source Mage]</ref> * [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]]<ref name="Ubuntu">[http://packages.ubuntulinux.org/testdisk TestDisk in Ubuntu]</ref>
